articles.headline: Can Quake-Prone Japan Ever Embrace Nuclear Energy Again?
articles.snippet: The government, its makeup in flux after the governing party lost seats this week, will soon need to make decisions that will shape Japan’s future nuclear policy.
articles.abstract: The government, its makeup in flux after the governing party lost seats this week, will soon need to make decisions that will shape Japan’s future nuclear policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade after one of the most devastating atomic-energy disasters in history, Japan was finally getting closer to reviving nuclear power.
articles.byline: By River Akira Davis and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: The Anti-D.E.I. Agitator That Big Companies Fear Most
articles.snippet: From his home in Tennessee, the social media rabble-rouser Robby Starbuck is waging war on “woke” policies at places like Lowe’s and Ford. His timing is impeccable.
articles.abstract: From his home in Tennessee, the social media rabble-rouser Robby Starbuck is waging war on “woke” policies at places like Lowe’s and Ford. His timing is impeccable.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early June, Robby Starbuck sat on the screened-in patio of his home in suburban Tennessee and recorded an eight-minute monologue on his mobile phone — a no-frills, TikTok-style video entitled “Exposed: Tractor Supply Went Woke.”

articles.headline: Working-Class Voters Are Pivotal. Both Candidates Are Vying for Their Support.
articles.snippet: Kamala Harris’s plans offer a bigger boost for the working class, but Donald Trump seems to be convincing voters.
articles.abstract: Kamala Harris’s plans offer a bigger boost for the working class, but Donald Trump seems to be convincing voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bernadette Daywalt had yet to decide whom to vote for in the presidential election. But the 69-year-old retiree said her decision would probably come down to economics.

articles.headline: Why There’s Hope for U.S. Factory Towns Laid Low by the ‘China Shock’
articles.snippet: Communities that suffered the worst of plant closings in recent decades are now gaining an outsize share of fresh investment and new jobs.
articles.abstract: Communities that suffered the worst of plant closings in recent decades are now gaining an outsize share of fresh investment and new jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the last half century, economic life in the heart of North Carolina has been dominated by factory closings, joblessness and downgraded expectations. Textile mills and furniture plants have been undercut by low-priced imports from Mexico and China. Tobacco processing jobs have disappeared.

articles.headline: Storms and Strikes Take a Toll on Pre-election Jobs Report
articles.snippet: U.S. payrolls grew by only 12,000 in October, a figure that left markets placid but fueled political contention. Unemployment remained 4.1 percent.
articles.abstract: U.S. payrolls grew by only 12,000 in October, a figure that left markets placid but fueled political contention. Unemployment remained 4.1 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Job creation stalled in October, a month battered by strikes and hurricanes, presenting an unclear picture of where the labor market was headed even as overall economic growth remained impressive.

articles.headline: They Barter and Trade to Survive. How Will They Vote?
articles.snippet: Many rural Americans engage in cashless barter systems to get food and firewood for heating and cooking. They value self-sufficiency, making them wary of government intervention.
articles.abstract: Many rural Americans engage in cashless barter systems to get food and firewood for heating and cooking. They value self-sufficiency, making them wary of government intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Miki Shiverick needs firewood to heat her home, or help clearing the rusted appliances and vehicles from her property, she doesn’t go to a store or pay for services. Instead, she trades for it.
